skills.name: Rotate an object or point 90° clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object
Rotate an object or point 180° about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object
Describe a 90° or 270° rotation giving the angle and direction of rotation, and the coordinates of the centre of rotation, where the centre of rotation lies on the edge or outside of the object

explanations.A: Remember 180° is half a turn. I think you have only done a quarter turn
explanations.B: You've used the correct angle, but the centre of rotation needs to be at the origin (0,0).
explanations.C: Not quite. I think you might have reflected in the line y=x. Try using tracing paper if you have it or counting the squares to the origin
explanations.D: When rotated 180 degrees, the shape P would rotate by a half turn. Point (-1,3) would rotate around to (1,-3).

explanations.C: Make sure to rotate the red point instead of one of the blue ones.
explanations.D: Make sure to rotate the red point instead of one of the blue ones.

explanations.A: The lowest point of the original shape is 2 left and 1 up from our centre. If we rotate this by a quarter turn clockwise we get 2 up and 1 right. This gives us Shape A.
explanations.B: You've rotated the shape using the correct angle and direction but you've used the incorrect centre of rotation
explanations.C: Not quite, you've rotated the shape 180° instead of 90°
explanations.D: Check the direction...it should be clockwise.

explanations.A: The bottom right point of the blue shape is currently 2 squares up from the centre (3,0). We need to rotate by 90 degrees clockwise so instead of travelling 2 squares up we need to travel 2 squares to the right. This gives us shape A
explanations.B: Nearly! I think you've used the centre (0,3) rather than (3,0). Remember in coordinates the x value comes first
explanations.C: Nearly! You've rotated the shape 180°, not 90°.
explanations.D: Almost! You rotated 90 degrees anticlockwise instead of clockwise.

explanations.A: Very close! You rotated 90 degrees clockwise instead of anti-clockwise.
explanations.B: Be careful with your centre of rotation, it should be (-2, 2). Try counting squares from one corner of the blue shape to this centre
explanations.C: Not quite! The centre of rotation isn't the origin in this question, it should be (-2, 2)
explanations.D: The bottom right point of the blue shape is currently 1 square up from the centre (-2,2). We need to rotate by 90 degrees anti-clockwise so instead of travelling 1 square up we need to travel 1 square to the left. This gives us shape D
